author: skyros
title: Prevent Attacks on Cardano
description: Malicious attackers can launch Distributed Denial-of-Truth (DDoT) attacks to undermine trust in the Cardano ecosystem.

f6_assessments.q0: This proposal details and highlights the needs that are being asked for this proposal challenge.  Given the experience that the proposal team is offering through Skyros it seems that they would be scalable and able to handle a variety of situations thrown to them.
f6_assessments.q1: This project is heavily relying on reputation to ensure the feasibility of a successful implementation of their proposal.  More details on how they would do this, what specific resources would be assigned and what they would do would make this proposal more confident in delivering what they are aiming to deliver.
f6_assessments.q2: This proposal lacks certain details on how it could be audited for success.  It is relying on contracting a 3rd party group to handle issues and although that group may have its own processes to address it, it would be nice to see some of those things highlighted here.

f6_assessments.q0: This proposal addresses this challenge in that the proposing team is part of an ethical hacker group and they are suggesting to customize their threat detection software for the Cardano network. They would employ and reward their team of ethical hackers to detect possible threats of misinformation before they occur, by monitoring the dark web and scanning chatter on the net through software and the work of the team from skyros.
f6_assessments.q1: Since the team is providing the website of the skyros service, proof of prior work and the provided information strongly points towards a highl likelyhood of this team contributing to the overall security of the Cardano network against DDoT attacks. Roadmap and budget seems realistic, the team also did a good job of explaining what they´re doing in non-technical manner without being just broad, I think this is a great skill and the proposal is very well written. Actionable steps are quite realistic.
f6_assessments.q2: The team provides information on their internal auditability of their team as well as a good overview on how they incentivise their team members, the roadmap is clear and easy to follow and they included that they would want to prove the value of work to the community. They did not, however, put up any information on how the community can track their progress or which channels they would use to keep us informed about the threats that they found, this is why I´m deducting one star of the rating.

f6_assessments.q0: The idea of using Skyros is very interesting and I see a lot of potential in this approach. However, it could have been further explored. The plan addresses the objectives because it focuses in preventing attacks and having the trust in the ecosystem being eroded. Notwithstanding, its impact could be bigger if they also focused in promoting truth about Cardano, this way even for newcomers it would be easier to identify what is true. Also, there is no discussion on building a repository for old/new scams and scam attempts which would be compelling given that newcomers might not even be aware of those attacks. The key metrics defined are a bit shallow and not only they could be more objective but also, they could have been broken down into more granular topics.
f6_assessments.q1: Skyros' network of hackers definitely has the necessary skills and experience to qualify for the task being proposed. However, nothing is said about who is leading the project and his/her experiences. The budget is broken down in three parts with reasonable funds requested each and the timetable presented is pretty reasonable. Nonetheless, the proposal misses an analysis of a potential need for additional resources and potential unexpected risks faced.
f6_assessments.q2: It is hard to affirm there is enough information in the proposal to audit its progress. There are just a few milestones, and they are too generic. No KPIs were defined in a clear manner as to allow auditability of advancements of the objectives. For instance, there is no objective way to tell if the hacking network is producing the results expected, how many potential attacks are discovered in relation to total avoided attacks broadcasted in the media and how fast the repository of scam attempts is growing.
f6_assessments.reply: The reviewer states that there is no objective way to tell if the hacking network is producing expected results. Then the reviewer states an objective way to determine that the network is working (ie. tracking the discovered attacks and comparing them with unexpected attacks). This review contradicts itself and should be removed.

f6_assessments.q0:
Preventing any form of cyber attack on Cardano aligns with this challenge brief .
Many of us rely solely on token and blockchain review to make decisions.  What if some or all of these reviews were "influenced" by a competitor? Could this actually destroy cardano, influence token price? After asking myself this question , I conclude that this proposal fit into this challenge and if implemented can impact the cardano ecosystem positively. I am concerned about the long term sustainability.
f6_assessments.q1: There is no identifying information about the team, the website provided also does not provided the Team members profile and their experiences, There is no actionable plan and road map how this will work. There is definition of success after 3 , 6 and 12 months which is good but not well detailed too.
f6_assessments.q2:
There's not enough information here to make this project auditable, The proposal does not described the skills needed for each team role . theres no target public launch date and the consideration of risk in implementing this Idea.
​​further work is required on roadmap and other areas.

f6_assessments.q0:
The proposal is well addressing the challenge. Using a network of hackers for threat detection is a known practice in the industry. This could be a great service providing important visibility to the community about the Cardano and Catalyst ecosystem resilience. 

It will have helped to have more information in the proposal about the problem as related to Cardano and the challenge.  There is some detailed information about the solution but it will be helpful having more details about the services and how they could impact Cardano. There is not much info on your website. You did provide some more info though replying to the feedback you got.
f6_assessments.q1:
The only information provided about the team is a website that does not have many details and does not show who is the team beyond it or track record of customers and achievements. It is very difficult to evaluate the feasibility without having more basic information. For example, how many team members, how many years of activities, customers, relevant use-cases, and so on. Throughout my career, I have used multiple external services and I believe more information is needed to make a decision. 

You provided some more info, responding to a question you got, and although you can not provide information about specific customers, there are ways to provide more information for example through use cases.

The proposal offers a realistic timetable to complete the work. More information about the technical adjustments needed would have been helpful to evaluate. 

The budget is outlined clearly and broken down into identifiable items. It could have been good to detail the distribution of the $20000 for the Hacking Network over the year. For example, a year cost per hacker is 3600, and that you will use 5 monthly hackers for this task. 

The budget requested is 33% of the proposal's available funds. Considering the lack of details about the team and company and the budget challenge, it could have made sense to present a smaller scope of work and maybe for 6 months so the community could better evaluate the services through a pilot project and then fund the second half of the year. I understand that there are initial adjustments and setting costs which might be a fix-cost but it is just a suggestion.
f6_assessments.q2:
The roadmap with milestones and quite clear from the proposal and the time horizon for achievement as well. 

The KPIs are listed but again you could provide more details about the expected results. It could have been helpful to see an example report from another client to create a full understanding. The definition of success is well explained.

f6_assessments.q0: The proposal offers an option to cooperate with Skyros's global hacker network and use threat detection software. I appreciate building detection software, but cooperating with a hacker network to detect it needs more clarification on how to do it as well as what are the benefits and risks? What does the effect look like, what methods do they use to detect ?
f6_assessments.q1: Is the $ 20,000 used for members in the attack network really effective?, who will the $300 monthly allowance pay? . The threat detection software has not yet stated its functions, how many servers and how much it costs for routine maintenance?. After detecting threats, how will be displayed to the community, I have not seen any mention.
f6_assessments.q2: It would be great to imagine how successful the results are for the community, what special features are added to the software, and how to communicate warnings to the community. Also, how does the proponent have a long-term development plan in the next funds?

solution: Partner with Skyros's global network of hackers and employ our threat detection software to discover attacks before they are launched.
experience: Skyros Intelligence is a security firm with expertise in ethical hacking and the dark/deep web.
